captions.text:
My name is Christian
von Koenigsegg.
I'm 40 years old.

And for half of my life I've
been on the quest to be a

leader in the hypercar industry,
utilizing Swedish

design combined with visionary
technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangars of

a former Swedish fighter
jet's squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back of
every Koenigsegg.
[CAR ENGINE]

So here we are at station
six out of seven in
our production line.

And I'm going to talk a little
bit about our rear suspension
on the car.

If you want a car to go fast,
and especially around a track

and in cornering and braking and
all of these aspects, it's

not enough with a
powerful engine.

You also need a chassis and a
suspension which is up to

snuff to get the power to
the ground, really.

So here we-- when I open this,
you can see what we call the
Triplex suspension.

First of all, it's
very unique.

And it really enables our car
to get maximum traction,
maximum level of comfort.

This is actually a
road car as well.

But with very little compromise
between comfort and
handling and stability.
[CAR ENGINE]

It's basically one extra shock
absorber connecting the rear
wheels together.

They have one shock absorber
each here going down into the

chassis with the spring
holding the car up.

But then there is this extra
shock absorber tying the
wheels together.

And underneath here you can see
our quite unique z-shaped
anti-roll bar.

So the reason why we developed
this third damper connecting

the sides together is that we
were getting so much power in

the car that we were getting
more and more squat during

take-off, which in one way
is good, to get traction.

But you don't want too much
movement in the car so it's

easy to handle and
that it's stable.

But you still want a lot
of traction, of course.
[CAR ENGINE]

Most manufacturers solved this
need by changing the geometry

of the suspension so the car
can't squat due to geometric
restriction.

The backside of doing that is
that it dilutes the geometry

that you need for cornering
and the
other parts of handling.

In a way, it's an anti-squat
damper.

It means we can have
a truer suspension
geometry than otherwise.

On top of that, it has other
side effects, as it is a new

dimension of dampening where you
have forces going from one
wheel to the other.

So for example, if you're
driving on a road which is a

little bit uneven from left to
right hand side, you have

independent movement of the
wheels, which is good.

But then you have the anti-roll
bar, which is there

to stabilize in cornering, which
you'd rather not even

have while driving straight on
a bumpy road, as it makes the

car feel a little bit less
comfortable than without it.

But what's interesting is that
this damper actually
counteracts the forces of the
anti-roll bar in that situation.

So when this wheel moves up on
a bump and this is not hit by

a bump, but you're still driving
straight, this link

here pushes the anti-roll bar
this direction, pulls a

similar link on this side that
direction, and wants to lift

this wheel up as well, which
causes on all cars with

anti-roll bars a certain
amount of harshness.

But when that is happening when
driving straight on a

road like that, this shock
absorber actually sends the

force to this side of the wheel,
counteracting the force

of the anti-roll bar, cancelling
that energy out.

So you get the same or similar
type of comfort in a straight

line as if you did not have an
anti-roll bar, which is a
great side effect.
[CAR ENGINE]

Also, the damping curves of this
shock absorber are very,
very special.

Basically it's focusing on
low-speed damping force.

So when you get high speed, when
you hit something harsh

and fast, basically it's
not doing much.
It's more for the lower-speed
dampening, where it's efficient.

So there are a lot of different
philosophies that

can be applied and that we can
enhance in the future.

But the starting point is to
reduce squat, increase

comfort, and reduce roll by the
fact that we can have a

stiffer anti-roll bar than
we otherwise could
have without it.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now at the front of the car, we
can see we have a similarly
complex suspension layout.

And actually here, everything
is very, very low, to have,

again, as low center of
gravity as possible.

But also we needed to make it
low to be able to get our roof

into the car, which is a
very unique feature.

So we couldn't have anything
in the way for the roof to
slide in here.

But it had the side effect of
actually also lowering the
center of gravity.

So that's a perfect example of
two needs working together
without compromise.
[CAR ENGINE]

Extreme [INAUDIBLE] technology,
extreme brake

technology, all of these systems
combined made it

possible for us to take the
world record from 0 to 300 to
0 kilometers per hour.

It's really all the systems
working together.

If one of the systems, like
suspension or brakes or engine

or gearbox, weren't up to the
task, we could not make a
record like that.

So it's all systems working
together, putting the power to

the ground, creating stability,
creating traction
and braking power.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text: What are those fans in the front used for?﻿
comments.author: CBCalifornia

comments.text:
It's not uncommon for a mid/rear-engine car to have the engine radiators at 
the front, where there is plenty of airflow.
comments.author: Timo E

comments.text:
The ones facing vertically? Those are used to pull air through the radiator 
at a stop.
comments.author: Porsche Curves

comments.text:
They are small fans, so I'm guessing that 1 fan is for passenger air 
conditioning and maybe the other 2 are to guide airflow into the brakes...

...or perhaps the car has some Venturi-principle mechanical-aerodynamic 
system, like the McLaren F1 has. That's just speculation, but the McLaren's 
Venturi system as implemented by Gordon Murray was quite the black art, yet 
apparently quite effective. It know that the system used fans. That 
Koenigsegg's fans look a little dinky to be handling high volumes of air, 
though, but I don't know much about high-performance fan tech :P

Anyway, the region of space right under the front valences of standard road 
cars can generates enormous air pressures at high speed. If you pop open 
the front hood of a Koenigsegg you see massive air ducting that is guiding 
air taken from under the front valence. Air is piped from the high-pressure 
area under the valence to those straked outflow ducts in front of the 
windshield, above the front tires: more front downforce for the car to work 
with.
comments.author: Paul Walnuts

comments.text:
Since there is only a damper and no spring, this Triplex system only works 
in transient conditions, which is desirable for this car, since excessively 
high ride stiffness on a relatively low downforce car will simply make it 
too uncomfortable and degrade tire grip.
comments.author: 4G12

comments.text:
This is basically a simplified version of what F-1 cars uses today in the 
form of a 3rd spring/damper coilover set at the rear. For F-1 cars, it 
allows for the necessarily high ride stiffness to support all that 
downforce without excessive roll stiffness.
comments.author: 4G12

comments.text:
Quite informative and entertaining, these videos, thanks DRIVE. Christian 
Von Koenigsegg doensn't cease to impress with his vast brakethrough ideias 
put on his cars, and they all seem to work wonders. Truly, this is a 
visionary man, and I salute him. What more can we expect in the near 
future? Hope I'll stick around to see.
comments.author: Pedro Pité Amaral

comments.text:

ingenuity to get there, nothing better.

comments.text:
The fact that you have to bring education into the discussion - yeah, I'd 
say you're an elitest ass. Which makes it even sadder that you generalize 
Americans as being "brainwashed patriotic redneck douchebags." First of all 
muthafucka, I'm black. No fucking redneck anywhere in my lineage. Second of 
all, I don't need an education to know that I'm not spending a $1M to tool 
around like some pussy engineer on a scooter in a 1200 hp car. The Veyron 
was being marketed as the fastest and it's not.
comments.author: 1stGenStunter

comments.text:
And lets be fair, the comment I wrote is absolute truth and realize, and 83 
smart people who upvoted it see that. The rest who flagged it as spam are 
just those american nationalist brainwashed patriotic redneck douchebags 
who think that everything american made is best in the world. I hope I 
pissed off some of those guys with this comment as well. It feels good to 
be able to control someone mood with just a few words because he's so 
thick.
comments.author: derbigpr500

comments.text:
And seriously, whoever compares a Venom to Veyron has absolutely no clue 
what he's talking about, because these are COMPLETELY different cars. Its 
like comparing a luxury private jet to some stunt airplane. And no, I'm not 
an elitist ass, I'm someone with actual education in mechanical engineering 
and understanding of why certain car is better than other, unlike the 
fanboys whose understanding of cars is limited to 0-60's, top speeds and 
quarter miles.
comments.author: derbigpr500

comments.text:
You sound like someone clueless enough about cars to not realize Veyron was 
never designed to be trashed around a track on track days. Its not a track 
car. Its a luxury grand tourer that happens to have 1000+ hp and is very 
fast. In terms of engineering put into it, its light years ahead of a 
Venom, and any other supercar. But in order to understand it, you need some 
extensive engineering knowledge, which you, or 99,9% of people comparing 
these two cars absolutely dont have.
comments.author: derbigpr500

comments.text:
Who buys a Veyron to drive it other than the way it's been marketed? I've 
never seen one in a serious time attack competition or a local track day 
going all out. They're just road jewelry. You sitting there conjuring up 
why the European supercars are better than the Venom is like Enzo Ferrari 
wondering how those little AC cars with the 289ci Ford engines were beating 
his ass. You sound like an elitest ass with an allegiance to elitest asses.
comments.author: 1stGenStunter

comments.text:
Let me see, the Texas Mile is held pretty darn close to Houston, which is 
where Hennessy is based. Why wouldn't he show up there? Kind of like 
Koenigsegg pops up on a certain M5board vids which is what, a mile race I 
believe? You guys kill me with "well, how civil is it blah, blah" when 
they're 1200+hp cars!!! These cars are built to go fast and fact is, in a 
mile race a PRODUCTION LOTUS would win against the Veyron and Agera R. Get 
over it. They're all engineered differently. Duh
comments.author: 1stGenStunter

comments.text:
u realize that the venom gt registered as a lotus so it infact not its own 
car and legal speaking is still a lotus no matter how modified no one is 
discrediting that the venom is fast but at the end of the day thats it it 
is in reality a lotus reengineered to be amile run car which it just so 
happens to be good at, it is no different then these guys runing 1500hp 
vettes and vipers in the for say the texas mile for this reason the 
koenigegg will no doubt be a better car with superior engineering
comments.author: kermit11234

comments.text:
Why are YOU comparing a Venom to a "tuned up" Impreza or Mustang? Those 
aren't considered production vehicles. What gives you internet pros the 
authority to establish what is/isn't a legitimate supercar? I don't 
understand the stupid loyalty some of you have towards cars that YOU WILL 
NEVER OWN built by manufacturers that could care less about your broke 
asses. The Venom is it's own car in it's own right with it's own VIN and it 
just so happens that the motherfucker is fast as shit. Get over it.
comments.author: 1stGenStunter

comments.text:
I'm glad that you mentioned the Venom GT. It just made a new record from 
0-300KMH, however, they are missing a key number which I'm sure they will 
probably never successfully achieve with that car: 0-300-"0". This is 
something I wouldn't have noted otherwise if I didn't see your post which 
truly opens my eyes to how different these cars with similar horse power 
truly are.
